pageData.text: Ecologists catalog  <button class='glossary-text'>population</button> size and species <button class='glossary-text'>diversity</button> for many reasons. For example, they must determine the number of individuals that can be safely removed from a population, plan controlled burns for forestry management, and determine community resilience to disruption. In the following activities, students will use two different sampling techniques—<button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>transects</button>—to estimate population size. Students will estimate population ground cover, use the <button class='glossary-text'>Shannon index</button> to estimate species richness, and use the <button class='glossary-text'>Simpson index</button> to estimate species diversity.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 45 minutes
Activity 1: Transect Method - 2 hours
Activity 2: Quadrat Method - 1 hour
Activity 3: Species Richness and Diversity Calculations - 1 hour

pageData.text: Activities 1 and 2 will be performed at a field site of your choosing. Times shown are for time required at the site to perform the activity.

pageData.text: A community is all the living things in an area and their interactions together. When you look at a community, you may be able to see the organisms, but the way those organisms, especially plants, are interacting may be less obvious. In forests, this is because much of the interaction actually takes place below the surface of the soil. Not only do forests have vast root networks for absorbing nutrients and water, but those roots also have symbiotic fungi which can provide connections between trees. These fungi, called mycorrhizae, live partially within the tree's roots while also sending out their own thin mycelia, increasing the surface area the tree can use to absorb these nutrients. The fungi network of one tree can then connect with those of another tree, creating a vast in-soil network which some have likened to a “forest internet”.  While there is still uncertainty about exactly how this network works, research suggests that these mycorrhizal fungi can help trees send out information such as distress signals from insect attacks or fire to other trees<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. The trees receiving these signals can then respond by preparing their defense mechanisms against those threats. They may also play a role in distributing water and nutrients to saplings and increasing forests’ ability to recover after disasters and adapt to change.

1Gorzelak, M. A., Asay, A. K., Pickles, B. J., & Simard, S. W. (2015). Inter-plant communication through mycorrhizal networks mediates complex adaptive behaviour in plant communities. AoB PLANTS, 7, plv050.
https://doi.org/10.1093/aobpla/plv050

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: Two trees at the edge of a forest.

pageData.text: is the study of the interactions between organisms and their environment. Groups of organisms and that interact with one another are collectively called an . Living organisms within an ecosystem comprise the . Nonliving components of the environment, such as water and inorganic compounds, are abiotic factors. Each biotic community is made up of several (groups of organisms of the same species). These populations are highly dependent on one another, either as prey, as shelter, or through other more complex relationships. Communities are frequently characterized by the most obvious (nonmoving) organisms (e.g., a pine forest or coral reef).

Ecologists study the environment for a number of reasons. In addition to increasing our understanding of the natural world, most studies seeking to characterize a community have some form of resource management as their goal. It is important to know, for instance, how many individuals are present in an environment when trying to determine hunting or catch limits. Frequently, just as important to understanding the function of the community and the impact of management on that community is the <button class='glossary-text'>diversity</button>, or variety, of the community. Communities that are more diverse are often more resilient to disruption in terms of the degree of a perturbation’s effects and in speed of recovery. Diversity is usually expressed as <button class='glossary-text'>total species richness</button>—the number of species found in an area.

<button class='glossary-text'>Evenness</button>, whether the numbers of individuals in various populations are similar, also affects functional diversity of a community. If two communities have similar total species richness, the diversity will be higher in the community with a more evenly distributed abundance.

Other management goals, however, require different measurements. For example, fire management practices use many of the same techniques to determine cover density, fuel load (the amount of flammable materials present in an environment), and the presence of rare species.

Ecological sampling techniques are based on the concept of a <button class='glossary-text'>representative sample</button>. It is uncommon for researchers to have either the time or money to exhaustively catalog every organism in a complex environment. Instead, they sample a subsection of the environment and assume it to be representative of the environment as a whole. Small sample sizes can easily miss rare organisms, so repeated sampling is important. Ideally, environments are sampled randomly to avoid the introduction of bias. Systematic sampling (sampling done at a fixed, periodic interval), however, may be more practical when the focus of the research is narrow, such as examining the transition between two environments. In this type of sampling, the chosen data is evenly distributed; the first sample is chosen at random, but the rest are taken based on a specific interval of choice.

pageData.question: How is diversity usually expressed in ecological studies?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Diversity is usually expressed as total species richness, which is the number of species found in an area.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the benefits of a diverse ecological community?

options.text: Diverse communities are usually more resilient to ecological disturbances.
Diverse communities have larger population sizes.
Diverse communities recover more slowly from ecological disturbances.
Diverse communities experience fewer natural disasters.
Diverse communities are more easily sampled by ecologists.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Communities that are more diverse are often more resilient to disruption in terms of the degree of a perturbation’s effects and in speed of recovery.

pageData.text: Different organisms must be surveyed in different ways. There are two major sampling techniques—<button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button> (Figure 1) and <button class='glossary-text'>transects</button>—for organisms that are <button class='glossary-text'>sessile</button> and/or in aquatic environments (e.g., plants, fungi, coral, and oysters). These methods can be employed separately or in combination.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Scientists observing square quadrats layed out on a rocky beach.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Scientists observing square quadrats layed out on a rocky beach.

pageData.text:
rocky_beach_quadrat.jpeg By USFWS Pacific Southwest Region OpenStax is available under Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic License at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/usfws_pacificsw/26373321933/in/photostream/

In practice, quadrats usually measure 0.5 m<sup>2</sup> or 1 m<sup>2</sup>, although they may be of any size. Researchers place quadrats throughout the test site and then inventory what they find inside of each. Critical to this sampling technique is the placement of quadrats throughout the habitat. If an external condition creates a bias in quadrat placement (e.g., resulting in the placement of quadrats where there appear to be higher concentrations of the target species), the subsequent statistical analyses will be inaccurate. The area to be studied can be divided into grids on a map, and quadrats can either be placed systematically or randomly on the grid. Figure 2 shows both of these sampling styles, with black outlined squares representing grids and orange squares inside of the grids representing quadrats.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Two quadrants, with one demonstrating systematic placement of quadrants on a grid and the other showing a random placement of quadrants on a grid
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two quadrants, with one demonstrating systematic placement of quadrants on a grid and the other showing a random placement of quadrants on a grid

pageData.text: The fastest and usually the least expensive method of determining the abundance and <button class='glossary-text'>diversity</button> of organisms within an area is the  <button class='glossary-text'>line transect</button>. In this method, a straight line is drawn between two points, usually by laying down a line of twine or string. Alternatively, the line may also be drawn on a larger scale by moving in a straight line from point A to point B; any organism touching the line is then identified and counted. <button class='glossary-text'>Transects</button> are frequently used to characterize change along a gradient. For example, researchers may look at changes in community structure in moving from an open field to a forested area or over distance from a body of water. This method has obvious drawbacks in a highly scattered environment, such as a savannah with clumps of trees or a stretch of coast dotted by tide pools; it also increases the probability of rare and/or small organisms being underrepresented in the data. One solution to this limitation is to use a belt transect, wherein two parallel lines are drawn at a fixed width apart from each other and all organisms between them are counted. Another solution is to combine <button class='glossary-text'>quadrats</button> and transects by placing a quadrat at either random intervals or at fixed points along a transect.

The choice of method and exact implementation of that method depend on a number of different factors, including time, budget, and scale of the habitat and study. Large mobile animals rarely stay in one place long enough to obtain accurate counts using the methods discussed in these activities.

This manual provides instructions for performing transect and quadrat sampling procedures. Since access to specific environments varies, please refer to your instructor’s directions for choosing a location for your sampling.Using the methods provided, you will collect data to calculate several indexes of species richness and diversity. Since estimates of species richness ( = total number of species) are highly dependent on sampling effort, species diversity is frequently reported relative to the total number of individuals sampled. The appropriate technique to use in creating such indexes has been the subject of much scientific debate. Two commonly used indexes are the (also called the Shannon-Weiner or Shannon-Weaver index), which measures species richness, and the , which is a measure of diversity. In both cases, is the proportion of a species in the community (i.e., the number of individuals counted of a given species divided by the total number of individuals counted of all species in the community). S is the total number of species in the community.

The formula for the Simpson index. D equals sigma, upper limit s and lower limit i equals 1, of p sub i squared.

pageData.question: Which of the following is true about quadrats and transects?

They are ideal for sampling mobile organisms.
They are described in this lab manual but will not be used in the activities.
They are always placed randomly in the sampling area.
They cannot be used for sampling aquatic environments.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Quadrats and transects can be employed separately or in combination. For example, a quadrat can be placed at either random intervals or at fixed points along a transect.

pageData.desc: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will cut the string and tie it to the flags for the transect and quadrat activities. Then, you will mark the string for the quadrat activity and travel to your field site. In activity 1, you will use the flags and string to mark the transect. Then you will photograph, identify and count the individuals of each species touching the transect. You will repeat this for 2 transects. In activity 2, you will use the flags and string to mark the quadrat. Then, you will photograph identify and estimate the percent coverage of each species in the quadrat.  In activity 3, you will calculate the pi for each species in the transect and use it to calculate the Simpson index and Shannon index for the transect. Then repeat for the second transect. Finally, you will calculate the percent ground cover for the transect.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Safety while performing fieldwork is of greatest importance. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following terms can be used to describe a community’s functional diversity?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.

To prepare for the sampling method before going into the field:
  1. Collect the string, scissors, and two flags.
  2. Measure and cut 3 m (300 cm) of string.
  3. Tie one end of the string to one flag. Carefully wind the remaining string around the flag so it will not tangle.

To prepare for the sampling method before going into the field:
  1. Collect the string, scissors, a marker, four flags, and the measuring tape.
  2. Measure and cut a little more than 4 m (400 cm) of string.
  3. Tie one end of the string to one flag.
  4. Measure 100 cm on the string from the flag, and mark the string with the marker.
  5. Continue to measure at 100-cm increments. There should be a mark at 100 cm, 200 cm, and 300 cm. Carefully wind the string around the flag so it will not tangle.
In Activity 1, you will go to a field site and set up two <button class='glossary-text'>transects</button>. You will then photograph, identify, and count the species along the transect.

Take supplies for both the <button class='glossary-text'>transect</button> method and <button class='glossary-text'>quadrat</button> method to your field site, and set aside the string prepared for the quadrat method.
Using the materials prepared for the transect method, push the flag with the string tied around it into the ground at the chosen start of the transect.

Walk in as straight a line as possible, letting the string unwind behind you to 3 meters in length for the transect. If you must detour around a tree trunk or an obstruction, return as soon as possible to the line of the transect. Pass the string over or through any shrubbery, keeping the line as close to straight and the string as close to the ground as possible.
When the string is completely unwound, tie the free end to a second flag and push this flag into the ground.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Identify and familiarize yourself with the different species of plants touching the transect. Take a photo of each type found for later reference. Your instructor may want you to identify each species using a local plant guide. Write a brief description of each in Data Table 1.

Count the number of individuals of each plant species touching the transect, and record it in Data Table 1. If there aren’t many plant species touching the transect, place your measuring tape on the ground at a right angle to a random spot on your transect and count the number of plant species touching the measuring tape.
Pick up the transect, and take the flags and string to a different location at the current site.
Repeat Steps 2–6 for a second transect. Collect all data for Transect 2, and record it in Data Table 2. Leave Transect 2 in place to use with Activity 2.

In Activity 2, you will set up a <button class='glossary-text'>quadrat</button> at your field site from Activity 1. You will then photograph and identify the species within the quadrat. You will then estimate the percent cover of each species in the quadrat.
Using the materials prepared for the <button class='glossary-text'>quadrat</button> method, choose a point at either end or at a random point along <button class='glossary-text'>Transect</button> 2.
Push the quadrat flag with the string tied around it into the ground at this point.
Run the string along a line perpendicular to the transect, and place your second flag at the first mark on your quadrat string.
Using a piece of paper or a notebook for geometric reference, run the string at a right angle to the first segment of string (see Figure 3).

pageData.disc: Figure 3: Diagram of quadrat, showing string forming a one-meter square with a flag at each corner of the square
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram of quadrat, showing string forming a one-meter square with a flag at each corner of the square

pageData.text: Place the third flag at the second mark along the string, and again, using paper or a notebook for geometric reference, run the string perpendicular to the second segment and parallel to the first.
Place the fourth flag at the third mark along the string. Run the string around the fourth flag and tie it off at the first flag.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Familiarize yourself with the different species of plants within your quadrat. Take a photo of each type found for later reference. Your instructor may want you to identify each species using a local plant guide. Write a brief description of each in Data Table 3.

Estimate the percentage of quadrat covered (or percent cover) for each plant type in your quadrat by looking down on your quadrat from above. Record each of these percentages in Data Table 3. When estimating percent cover, it may be useful to imagine a grid overlaying your quadrat, or if you want to be more precise, use the remaining string on the roll provided to mark out the grid. Determine how many of those smaller squares are occupied by each plant species, then divide that number by the total number of squares. Remember that you are measuring how much of the ground is covered by each plant and not how much of the ground is covered. Because the area occupied by each plant species often overlaps with that of another species, the sum of these percentages will likely be more than 100%.

In Activity 3, you will calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>Simpson index</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>Shannon index</button> for each <button class='glossary-text'>transect</button>. Then you will calculate the total percentage of ground cover for the species found in the <button class='glossary-text'>quadrat</button>.

pages.pageTitle:
A
  Species Richness and Diversity Calculations (08 steps)

pageData.text: Calculate the total number of individuals (N). This is the sum of all the individuals of each species (ni) for 1. Record N in Data Table 1.
Calculate for each species, and record the value in Data Table 1.pi = ni/N
Calculate pi2 for each species, and record the value in Data Table 1.pi2 = pi x pi
Calculate the . This is the sum of all pi2 values for the species in Data Table 1. Record this value in Data Table 1.

pageData.disc: The formula for the Simpson index. D equals sigma, upper limit s and lower limit i equals 1, of p sub i squared.
pageData.altText: The formula for the Simpson index. D equals sigma, upper limit s and lower limit i equals 1, of p sub i squared.

pageData.text: Calculate piln(pi) for each species, and record the value in Data Table 1.piln(pi) = pi x ln(pi)
Calculate the . This is the negative sum of all pi ln(pi) values for the species in Data Table 1. Record this value in Data Table 1.

pageData.disc: The formula for the Shannon index. H prime equals negative sigma, upper limit s and lower limit i equals 1, of p sub i natural log of p sub i.
pageData.altText: The formula for the Shannon index. H prime equals negative sigma, upper limit s and lower limit i equals 1, of p sub i natural log of p sub i.

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 1–6 for Transect 2, and record the values in Data Table 2.

Calculate the total percentage of ground cover for the species found in the in Data Table 3. This is the sum of the percentages in Data Table 3. This value may be more than 100%. Record the value in Data Table 3.
Before leaving the field site, pick up the string, flags, and any other material you brought with you to return to your home.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will cut the string and tie it to the flags for the transect and quadrat activities. Then, you will mark the string for the quadrat activity and travel to your field site. In activity 1, you will use the flags and string to mark the transect. Then you will photograph, identify and count the individuals of each species touching the transect. You will repeat this for 2 transects. In activity 3, you will calculate the pi for each species in the transect and use it to calculate the Simpson index and Shannon index for the transect. Then repeat for the second transect. Finally, you will calculate the percent ground cover for the transect.

data.title: Abiotic factor
data.content: A non-living component of an ecosystem

data.title: Biotic community
data.content: The living organisms within an ecosystem

data.title: Ecology
data.content: The study of interactions between organisms and their environment

data.title: Ecosystem
data.content: A group of organisms and abiotic factors that interact with one another

data.title: Evenness
data.content: The measure of the similarity between population sizes

data.title: Line transect
data.content: A transect technique in which a straight line is drawn between two points in a habitat

data.title: pi
data.content: The proportion of a species in the community

data.title: Population
data.content: A group of organisms of the same species

data.title: Quadrat
data.content: One of a series of squares of a set size placed in a habit for the purposes of species sampling

data.title: Representative sample
data.content: A subset of a population that features the same diversity as the total population

data.title: S
data.content: The total number of species in a community

data.title: Shannon index
data.content: An index that measures species richness

data.title: Total species richness
data.content: The number of species found in an area

data.title: Transect
data.content: A line drawn between two points in a habitat for the purposes of sampling
